metadata.case_name: Krishna Gopal v. P. C. Sethi

facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 4 were candidates in the election to the Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly from Mhow constituency in Indore district in March 1972.
Respondent No. 4 withdrew his candidature and the contest took place between the appellant and respondents 1 to 3.
Result of the election declared on March 12, 1972 and respondent No. 1 declared elected.

On April 25, 1972 the appellant presented an election petition under section 81 of the Act to the Madhya Pradesh High Court challenging the election of respondent No. 1, numbered Election Petition 11 of 1972.
Election Petition 11/1972 and some other election petitions entrusted by then Chief Justice Bishan Shambhar Dayal CJ to Vyas J sometime in July or August 1972.
Vyas J. was sitting on the Indore Bench of the Madhya Pradesh High Court.
Surajbhan J. of the Madhya Pradesh High Court retired on February 2, 1971.
After obtaining previous consent of the President, Chief Justice requested Surajbhan J. to sit and act as judge under article 224A from April 28, 1971.
Surajbhan J.'s last appointment under article 224A by President's consent dated November 23, 1972, to last for one year or till disposal of election petitions entrusted to him, whichever earlier.
Vyas J. dealt with the election petition till June 1973.
On June 2, 1973 present Chief Justice directed Vyas J. to sit on Gwalior Bench.
After direction to Gwalior, Vyas J. came to Indore for trial of assigned election petitions.
On June 20, 1973 Vyas J. addressed letter to Chief Justice setting out stage of different election petitions.
Chief Justice letter to Vyas J. on July 19, 1973.
Vyas J. reply letter dated August 5, 1973 requesting that E.P. No. 11/72 Krishna Gopal Vs. P. C. Sethi etc. be heard by someone at Indore to avoid his visits and for early disposal.
Chief Justice endorsed on margin: 'He has to try them.'

On August 20, 1973 Chief Justice passed order under Sec 80A(2) directing Election Petition No. 11/1972 Krishna Gopal v. P. C. Sethi to be tried by Justice Surajbhan Grover at Indore Bench, superseding earlier order.
Proceedings continued before Vyas J.; last hearing August 22, 1973, order for filing reply to interim applications and send record to Registry at Jabalpur for Chief Justice.
Issues framed on merits but no evidence recorded.
On August 27, 1973 Deputy Registrar intimated appellant's counsel that hearing at Indore, arguments on interim applications on September 10, 1973.
On September 10, 1973 application filed by appellant that petition allocated to Vyas J., Surajbhan J. has no jurisdiction, should be tried by Vyas J.
On September 11, 1973 Surajbhan J. dismissed application stating Vyas J. released petition, Chief Justice competent to assign to another judge.
On September 13, 1973 appellant filed application that he was not heard on jurisdiction issue.
Fresh arguments heard, application dismissed by Surajbhan J. on October 9, 1973 holding he has jurisdiction and Chief Justice order not infirm.
On September 27, 1973 appellant filed writ petition under Art 226 for mandamus directing Surajbhan J. not to proceed and Vyas J. to complete trial.
Writ petition before Division Bench Sen and Soni JJ., dismissed repelling contentions.
High Court granted certificate under Art 132 on application by appellant.

legal_issues.text: Whether a person sitting and acting as a judge of the High Court under article 224A of the Constitution can exercise the jurisdiction to try an election petition under section 80A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Whether the Chief Justice of the High Court can after entrusting an election petition to one judge allocate it at his request to another judge.

petitioner_arguments.text: A person sitting and acting as a judge under article 224A is not a judge of the High Court for purpose of section 80A(2) of the Act, so Surajbhan J. has no jurisdiction.
Even if Surajbhan J. is a judge, after entrustment to Vyas J., Chief Justice cannot reallocate the petition.

respondent_arguments.text: Surajbhan J. is a judge under Art 224A with full jurisdiction, powers and privileges; Chief Justice can reallocate especially at request of Vyas J.

court_reasoning.text: Jurisdiction to try election petition vests in High Court under Sec 80A(1), exercised by single judge assigned by CJ under Sec 80A(2); provisions mandatory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sub-section 2 specifies instrumentality for exercise of jurisdiction vested in High Court.

court_reasoning.text: Art 224A: Person requested sits and acts as judge, has all jurisdiction, powers, privileges of judge though not otherwise deemed a judge; for jurisdiction etc. is a judge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'While so sitting and acting' and 'shall not otherwise be deemed' imply full judicial powers.

court_reasoning.text: Words 'otherwise' mean in other respects; not for transfer under Art 222 etc., but is judge for jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deemed shows legal fiction only for non-judicial purposes.

court_reasoning.text: Similar to Art 128, English Act; rejecting contention avoids rendering Art 224A dead letter.
Vyas J. requested reallocation in letter Aug 5, 1973 for convenience and early disposal; no bar in Sec 80A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: CJ can relieve judge at his request; Zikar case inapplicable as not withdrawal without concurrence.

holdings.text: Person under Art 224A is judge of High Court for Sec 80A(2) purposes and can try election petitions if assigned by CJ.
CJ can reallocate election petition at request of assigned judge; no legal infirmity.
Contentions not well founded, but in interest of justice, direct trial by permanent judge assigned by CJ.

precedents_cited.relevance: CJ cannot withdraw from Division Bench without concurrence, but inapplicable to single judge requesting relief.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art 224A empowers retired judge to sit and act with full jurisdiction; overriding effect.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court tries petitions; exercised by single judge assigned by CJ; mandatory.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court repelled appellant's contentions on jurisdiction of Art 224A judge and reallocation power, upholding High Court view, but set aside Chief Justice's order dated August 20, 1973 and directed that election petition be tried by a permanent judge assigned by Chief Justice in interest of justice.
outcome.relief_granted: Election petition to be tried by permanent judge assigned by CJ; order of Aug 20, 1973 set aside.

key_quotes.text: "every such person so requested shall, while so sitting and acting, be entitled to such allowances as the President may by order determine and have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges of, but shall not otherwise be deemed to be, a Judge of that High Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key language of Art 224A interpreted to confer full judicial powers.

key_quotes.text: "The words 'but shall not otherwise be deemed to be a judge of that Court' indicate that in matters not relating to jurisdiction, powers and privileges the person so requested shall not be deemed to be a judge."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Crux of reasoning on scope of Art 224A.

key_quotes.text: "It is inconceivable that the framers of the Constitution inserted an article which was in the nature of a dead letter."
key_quotes.speaker: court
